pros:
Very technical, have to read up or ask around to know what is going on. I'm sure technical knowledge will improve after working here. Nice BI training session given by tech team! 

Contrary to other reviews (I read all before interviewing), management is flexible and willing to listen to employees. Though it's a startup and has a flat structure, there are surprisingly already alot of things in place like long-term stock options, good pantry, open performance review showing that the company is vested in attracting and retaining talents, this is foresight that an SME I worked at before didn't have. 

Also, work load has been challenging and satisfying so far. I can see how my tasks contribute to a greater purpose and how others initiate suggestions or changes to projects I am already on. I make sure to strike a good work-life balance and not work too much after work hours unless an urgent task calls for it, which really should be the case in any company! (Don't know why Singapore has this workaholic culture)

Although communication is not perfect, company really tried to make sure everyone is on the same page with frequent weekly supervisor check-ins and regular monthly company video calls, even before WFH started. 

To my relief, everyone is pretty nice and not much politics or racism here whew
cons: Some of my colleagues around me don't set those work-life boundaries and are working too long hours. I don't know if they don't want to or can't achieve that balance but I'm pretty sure that they are burning out. So it would be good to structure job tasks and deadlines more reasonably and for management to have more patience regarding implementation of certain projects that may take a longer time.

- Company support for WFH. It's been more than a year now
- Other benefit like monthly event allowance
- The team has been supportive and look after each other
- Some of the managers has a great leadership and capable in doing what they're doing
- Good place if you're looking for first experience working in Startup Company
cons:
- Micro Managing
- High volatility of changes. Understand this is a startup but if you change some key strategy or game plan oftentimes, people will think the management doesn't know what to do.
- Slow growth in terms of features and customers
- In some cases, they do not comply with the applicable regulations in the countries where the company operates
- Unknown benchmark of salary. Some people are paid quite a lot for jobs they can't do and what's worse, their work experience has nothing to do with the position they currently occupy.

job_title: Credit Relationship Officer in Ho Chi Minh City
pros:
I previously worked for very big and structured companies hence moving to a startup like Aspire has left a huge impression to me. I can say that there are a few Pros of working for Aspire compared to other corporations:
1) The culture is more open which you can easily express your ideas 
2) You can learn about a lot of aspects of a business, from Finance, Risk, Strategy to Legal
3) International exposure. I worked directly with the Regional team in the very first months of joining, whereby other companies might take 6-9 months for you to be able to do such contribution
4) Flexible working environment
cons: Working for an early-stage startup always associates with lots of pressure and tight deadline. Things are also changing very quick, hence agility is required. However, I find it enjoyable
